questions.text: A 10-week-old fetus is found to have a developmental anomaly affecting the iris muscles and the posterior pituitary. Which of the following is directly involved in the formation of these structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neuroectoderm

Explanation:

  • Neural plate ectoderm derivatives include various structures of the central nervous system and associated tissues, specifically:
    • Iris muscles (Dilator pupillae and sphincter pupillae) are derived from the neuroectoderm.
    • Neurohypophysis (posterior pituitary) is also derived from the neuroectoderm, specifically from an extension of the diencephalon.
    • Retina, optic nerve, ciliaris
    • Membranous labyrinth
  • Neural plate is a cohesive structure whose cells are linked together by junctional complexes.
  • There are structural changes that occur within neuroepithelial cells of the neural plate that contribute to the formation of the neural groove and then the neural tube.

Surface ectoderm

Neuroectoderm

Neural crest cell
  • Epidermis of the skin
  • Hair
  • Nails
  • Sweat & Sebaceous glands
  • Mammary glands
  • Enamel of the teeth
  • Lens of eye
  • Epithelium of sensory organs in the inner ear & nose
  • Anterior lobe of the pituitary gland
  • Central nervous system (Brain and spinal cord)
  • Peripheral nervous system
  • Retina
  • Sensory epithelia of nose & ear
  • Pineal gland
  • Posterior lobe of the pituitary gland
  • Sensory ganglia of the spinal nerves( dorsal root ganglia)
  • Sensory ganglia of the cranial nerves
  • Autonomic ganglia Meninges (Pia mater & Arachnoid mater) of the brain & spinal cord
  • Schwann cells
  • Melanoblasts of the skin
  • Suprarenal medulla (chromaffin cells)
  • Several skeletal & muscular components in the head (derived from pharyngeal arches)
  • Parafollicular C cells

 

Embryonic tissue

Eye tissue







 

Ectoderm

  

Neuroectoderm
  • Retina
  • Pigmented epithelium of iris
  • Retinal pigment epithelium
  • Dilator & sphincter muscles of iris
  • Optic nerve


 

Neural crest cell
  • Corneal stroma & endothelium
  • Trabecular meshwork
  • Ciliary muscles
  • Melanocytes
  • Schwann cells
  • Meningeal sheath of optic nerve
  • Vitreous
 

Surface Ectoderm
  • Conjunctiva
  • Surface epithelium of cornea
  • Lens
  • Lacrimal gland

Mesoderm
  • Eye muscles(EOM)
  • Endothelium of all eye structures

 

Neural crest cells (Option A) originate from the edge of the neural tube and contribute to various peripheral structures, including parts of the PNS and some facial bones.

 

Surface ectoderm (Option B) primarily forms the outer skin layers, sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and other structures.

 

Epiblast cells (Option D) are early embryonic cells that give rise to the three germ layers.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant shows signs of a developmental abnormality involving the formation of tongue muscles. Which group of somites is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Occipital somites

 

Explanation:

Occipital somites contribute to the formation of the muscles of the tongue.

 

Paraxial Mesoderm:

  • Extends as a longitudinal column on either side of the notochord and the developing neural tube.
  • Developing otic capsules (neuroectodermal thickenings that form the membranous labyrinth of the internal ear) divide the paraxial mesoderm into preotic and postotic parts.
  • Preotic Paraxial Mesoderm: Comprises unsegmented head mesoderm, known as somitomeres.
  • Postotic Paraxial Mesoderm: Forms somites

Somites:

  • Paraxial mesoderm becomes segmented to form 42-44 pairs of somites develop on either side of the neural tube and notochord.
  • Appear between the 20th and 30th day, marking the 4th week as the somite period.
  • Somite Structure:
    • Sclerotome: Ventromedial part; forms vertebral column and ribs.
    • Dermatome: Lateral part; forms dermis of skin and subcutaneous tissue.
    • Myotome: Intermediate part; forms striated muscle.

  • Innervation:
    • Cervical, thoracic, lumbar, and sacral regions: One spinal nerve innervates each myotome (no. of somites = no. of spinal nerves) .
    • Coccygeal region: Somites exceed spinal nerves and many degenerate.

Somites

Number of Pairs

Skeletal Elements

Musculature

Preoccipital (Option C)

3

Base of skull

Extraocular muscles of eyeball

Occipital (Option B)

4 - 5

Tongue musculature except palatoglossus

Cervical (Option A)

8

Vertebra

Striated muscles of trunk, diaphragm, limbs

Thoracic (Option D)

12

Vertebra and ribs

Lumbar

5

Vertebra

Sacral

5

Coccygeal

8 - 10

questions.text: If the development of the endoderm is negatively affected and fails to normally differentiate, which of the following glands would not be affected by this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anterior pituitary

 

Explanation:

The pituitary gland develops from the ectoderm, and hence, an improper differentiation of the endoderm would not affect it.

 

Glands developed from ectoderm and endoderm:

Ectoderm

Endoderm

Neural ectoderm:

  • Posterior pituitary
  • Connective tissue of thymus
  • Connective tissue of thyroid and parathyroids
  • Adrenal medulla
  • Connective tissue of lacrimal, nasal, labial, palatine, oral, and salivary glands
  • Thymus glands (parenchyma)
  • Parathyroid glands (parenchyma) (Option B)
  • Liver
  • Pancreas (Option D)
  • Follicular cells of thyroid (Option A)
  • C cells of thyroid
  • Prostate
  • Urethral glands

 

Surface ectoderm:

  • Rathke’s pouch gives rise to the anterior pituitary (Option C)
  • Sweat glands and sebaceous glands
  • Parotid, sublingual, submandibular salivary glands
  • Mammary glands
  • Lacrimal glands

questions.text: Which of the following statements about yolk sac development is correct?

choices.text: Primary yolk sac is lined by cuboidal cells.
Secondary yolk sac is lined by flattened cells.
Primary yolk sac forms by the end of the first week
Tertiary yolk sac connects to the midgut via the vitellointestinal duct.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tertiary yolk sac connects to the midgut via the vitellointestinal duct.

 

Explanation:

Tertiary yolk sac communicates with the midgut via the vitellointestinal duct.

 

Development of Yolk Sac:

  • Yolk sac is an endodermal sac lying ventral to the embryonic disc.
  • Considered a vestigial structure in humans with hardly any nutritive yolk inside it.
  • Develops from the cavity of blastocyst (blastocele).
  • 3 stages of development:
    • Primary yolk sac:
      • Blastocyst cavity (blastocele) becomes the primary yolk sac when it is lined by Heuser’s membrane (flattened cells from endoderm of embryoblast). (Option A)
      • Heuser's membrane attaches to the undersurface of the embryonic disc.
      • Formed by the end of the second week. (Option C)

  • Secondary yolk sac:
    • With the formation of extraembryonic coelom, the primary yolk sac becomes smaller and is termed as secondary yolk sac.
    • Cells lining the yolk sac become cuboidal. (Option B)​​​​

  • Tertiary (definitive) yolk sac:
    • Remnant of the secondary yolk sac.
    • As the embryo folds, most of the yolk sac is incorporated into the embryo to form the primitive gut.
    • Remaining portion not absorbed into the embryo is termed as tertiary/definitive yolk sac.
    • It communicates with the midgut via the vitellointestinal duct. (Option D)

  • Functions of Yolk Sac: 
  1. Hemopoiesis: Produces blood for the embryo until the liver is formed during the sixth week.
  2. Primitive gut formation: Dorsal portion of the yolk sac forms the primitive gut.
  3. Primordial germ cells formation: Primordial germ cells form from the yolk sac wall and migrate to the developing gonads during the fourth week, where they develop into primitive germ cells (spermatogonia or oogonia).
  4. Allantois formation: A small diverticulum called the allantois arises from the caudal part of the yolk sac.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the lamina terminalis is incorrect?

choices.text: It forms the anterior wall of the third ventricle.
It gives rise to the septum pellucidum.
The lamina terminalis is located at the caudal end of the prosencephalon.
The first commissural fibers to develop pass through the lamina terminalis.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) The lamina terminalis is located at the caudal end of the prosencephalon.

 

Explanation:

  • The lamina terminalis is the part of the neural tube wall that closes the cranial end of the prosencephalon. (Option C)
  • It lies in the anterior wall of the third ventricle after the appearance of the telencephalic vesicles. (Option A)
  • The lamina terminalis forms the commissural plate, which allows neural fibers to pass between hemispheres.
  • Commissural fibers:
    • Anterior commissure (first to develop). (Option D)
    • Hippocampal commissure/fornix (second).
    • Corpus callosum (largest, forms later and extends backward, roofing over the diencephalon).
    • The septum pellucidum persists from the portion of the lamina terminalis between the corpus callosum and fornix. (Option B)
    • Other commissures include the optic chiasma, habenular commissure, and posterior commissure.

questions.text: The cecal bed arises from which part of the embryonic gut?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Post-arterial segment of Midgut

 

Explanation:

  • The postarterial segment of the midgut loop gives off a cecal bud.
  • The cecum and appendix are formed by enlargement of this bud.

 

Derivatives of Midgut:

  • Prearterial segment:
    • Duodenum: Descending (second) part distal to the major papilla; horizontal (third) and ascending (fourth) parts
    • Jejunum
    • Ileum except the terminal part.
  • Postarterial segment:
    • Terminal ileum
    • Cecum and appendix
    • Ascending colon
    • Right two-thirds of the transverse colon.

questions.text: The stomatodeum is derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Ectoderm

 

Explanation:

  • The stomatodeum (future mouth) is a depression bounded cranially by a bulging produced by the brain, and caudally by a bulging produced by the pericardial cavity.
  • It is derived from the ectoderm.
  • It forms the oral epithelium, including the lips, teeth, and part of the palate.

Endoderm (Option B) contributes to the internal lining of the gastrointestinal tract but is not responsible for the stomatodeum.

 

Mesoderm (Option C) contributes to structures such as muscles and connective tissues but not to the stomatodeum directly.

 

Neural Crest Cells (Option D) contribute to structures like the face and skull but do not form the stomatodeum.

questions.text: What is the correct sequence of events in the maturation of the lungs?

choices.text: Canalicular phase → Pseudoglandular phase → Alveolar phase → Saccular phase.
Pseudoglandular phase → Canalicular phase → Saccular phase → Alveolar phase.
Saccular phase → Alveolar phase → Pseudoglandular phase → Canalicular phase.
Alveolar phase → Canalicular phase → Saccular phase → Pseudoglandular phase.

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Pseudoglandular phase → Canalicular phase → Saccular phase → Alveolar phase.

 

Explanation:

The development of the lungs follows a well-defined sequence:

  • Pseudoglandular phase (5–16 weeks): Formation of terminal bronchioles.
  • Canalicular phase (16–26 weeks): Formation of respiratory bronchioles and capillary networks.
  • Saccular phase (26–36 weeks): Formation of primitive alveoli and and capillaries establish close contact.
  • Alveolar phase (36 weeks–postnatal): Formation of mature alveoli and blood-air barrier.

Premature Birth and RDS:

  • The onset of surfactant production in the canalicular phase and its increase during the saccular phase is essential for preventing alveolar collapse.
  • Premature infants born before 34 weeks are at significant risk for Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS) due to insufficient surfactant production and immature alveolar development.
  • Treatment includes surfactant replacement therapy and supportive ventilation.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is derived from the endodermal lining of the laryngotracheal tube?

choices.text: Muscular components of the respiratory tract

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Alveolar epithelial cells

 

Explanation:

The alveolar epithelial cells (Type I and Type II) are derived from the endoderm of the laryngotracheal tube.

 

Derivatives of the Laryngotracheal Tube:

  • The laryngotracheal tube develops from the foregut and gives rise to critical structures in the respiratory system.
  • Endodermal Derivatives:
    • Endoderm: Forms the lining of the larynx, trachea, bronchi, and alveoli, including the Type I and Type II alveolar cells.
  • Mesodermal Derivatives:
    • Splanchnic Mesoderm: Forms the cartilage, smooth muscle, and visceral pleura of the respiratory tract.
    • Somatic Mesoderm: Forms the parietal pleura lining the thoracic cavity.

 

Developmental Stages:

  • 4th week: The lung bud appears as an outgrowth from the foregut.
  • 4-5th weeks: The tracheoesophageal septum forms, separating the foregut into the trachea and esophagus.
  • Subsequent weeks: Primary, secondary, and tertiary bronchi form, leading to the adult bronchopulmonary segments.

questions.text: Which of the following is the first sign of respiratory development?

choices.text: Development of type I alveolar cells

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Appearance of the lung bud

 

Explanation:

  • The first sign of respiratory development is the appearance of the lung bud (also called the respiratory diverticulum)
  • It appears as an outgrowth from the ventral wall of the foregut around the 4th week of embryonic development.
  • Development depends on retinoic acid (RA) produced by adjacent mesoderm, which upregulates the transcription factor TBX4.
  • This marks the initiation of lung formation and the beginning of the respiratory system's development.

 

Formation of primary bronchi (Option A) occurs later in development, around the 5th week.

Development of type I alveolar cells (Option C): Type I alveolar cells, which are involved in the formation of the blood-air barrier, begin to form later during the canalicular phase (16–26 weeks).

Formation of the tracheoesophageal septum (Option D) occurs shortly after the appearance of the lung bud and serves to separate the respiratory tract from the esophagus. This process occurs during the 4th to 5th week.

questions.text: Which of the following embryological structures contributes to the development of the post-renal segment of the inferior vena cava?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Right supracardinal vein

 

Explanation:

The Post-renal (Infra-renal) segment of the Inferior vena cava (IVC) develops primarily from the right supracardinal vein.

Formation of IVC:

  • The beginning of the IVC is called the Posterior cardinal vein.
  • Posterior cardinal vein contributes to Sacro cardinal vein.
  • Kidneys drain into the inferior vena cava with the help of renal veins.
  • Right supracardinal vein contributes the Post-renal (infra-renal) segment of the IVC.
  • Right subcardinal vein contributes the Renal and Pre-renal (suprarenal) segment of IVC.
  • Terminal portion of the IVC is contributed by the right sided vitelline veins.
  • The right sided vitelline veins will contribute to the right Hepatiocardiac channel.
  • All this happen in the right side whereas Left sided veins will disappear.
  • There is Anastomosis between:
    • Supracardinal and Subcardinal vein
    • Subcardinal and hepatocardiac channel

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is found to have a persistent left-sided superior vena cava (SVC) during routine imaging. What is the most likely cause of this anomaly?

choices.text: Failure of right-sided SVC to develop
Abnormal development of the left anterior cardinal vein
Persistence of the left umbilical vein
Abnormal development of the right posterior cardinal vein

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Abnormal development of the left anterior cardinal vein

 

Explanation:

A persistent left-sided SVC arises from the left anterior cardinal vein, which typically regresses during fetal development.

 

  • Normal Development:
    • The right anterior cardinal vein forms the right SVC.
    • The left anterior cardinal vein regresses, with its remnant forming the left brachiocephalic vein, which connects the left and right venous systems.

 

  • Persistent Left-Sided SVC:
    • Occurs due to the failure of the left anterior cardinal vein to regress.
    • This results in the formation of a left-sided SVC, which drains into the right atrium through the coronary sinus.
    • The right SVC typically develops normally.

 

  • Double SVC:
    • If the left brachiocephalic vein fails to form, the left anterior cardinal vein persists as a separate venous channel.
    • In this condition:
      • The right anterior cardinal vein forms the right SVC.
      • The left anterior cardinal vein persists as the left SVC.

A. Left superior vena cava draining into the right atrium by way of the coronary sinus

B. Double superior vena cava. The communicating [brachiocephalic] vein between the two

anterior cardinals has failed to develop

questions.text: The structure “b” fuses with structure “c” during the 3rd month of pregnancy. Identify the structure “c”.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Decidua parietalis

 

Explanation:

The structure “c” is decidua parietalis that fuses with the growing decidua capsularis around the embryo.

 

Three types of decidua:

Decidua basalis/Serotina (Option B ruled out)

Decidua capsularis/Reflexa (Option A ruled out)

Decidua parietalis/Vera

  • This forms the maternal component of the placenta
  • The maternal spiral arteries grow and dilate to form sinusoids with blood
  • Contains large decidual cells rich in lipids and glycogen (may be a source of nutrition for the embryo)
  • Firmly attached to the chorion
  • Separates the embryo from the uterine cavity
  • Covers the embryo like a capsule
  • Lines the rest of the uterine cavity
  • With the progression of the pregnancy, the decidua capsularis grows with the fetus and finally fuses with the parietalis during the 3rd month and obliterates the uterine cavity.
  • The decidua is eventually shed off with the placenta and membranes after delivery.


Myometrium (Option C): is labelled as structure "d" in the image

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about villi?

choices.text: The secondary villi have a central core of cytotrophoblast
The uteroplacental circulation begins only after the formation of tertiary villi
The tertiary villi have a mesoderm core that carries the fetal blood
The primary villi have a core of extraembryonic mesoderm

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The tertiary villi have a mesoderm core that carries the fetal blood

 

Explanation:

  • The tertiary villi are formed with the extraembryonic mesoderm core filled with fetal blood, which establishes the fetoplacental circulation.
  • The chorion is formed by the extraembryonic somatic mesoderm, cytotrophoblast, and syncytiotrophoblast.
  • The chorionic villi formed from the chorion cover the chorionic sac (extraembryonic coelom) until the beginning of the 8th week.


According to the structure of the chorionic villi at different periods of embryonic development they are divided into:

Primary villi

Secondary villi

Tertiary villi
  • A central core of cytotrophoblast (Option D) covered by a layer of syncytiotrophoblast.
  • Intervillous space separates the villus from each other.

Has 3 layers:

  • Outer syncytiotrophoblast
  • Intermediate cytotrophoblast
  • Inner extraembryonic mesoderm (Option A)

Similar to secondary villi but have fetal blood capillaries in the mesoderm

Formation of the villi:

  • Appearance of lacunae and trabeculae (around the 12th day of gestation):
    • Small cavities appear in the rapidly growing and thick syncytiotrophoblast.
    • These cavities are called lacunae and they increase in size and arrange themselves from irregular to a radial design around the blastocyst.
    • The syncytium separates them from one another, forming partitions called trabeculae, which in time get surrounded by lacunae as they communicate with each other and one large space is formed.

  • Erosion of maternal endometrium:
    • The endometrium of the maternal uterus is eroded by the growing syncytiotrophoblasts, which leads to the opening of some blood vessels and the leaking of blood into the lacunar space (uteroplacental circulation). (Option B)
  • Formation of chorionic villi:
    • Once the cytotrophoblast grows into the trabeculae, it becomes a two-layered structure with a core of cytotrophoblast covered by a layer of syncytiotrophoblast and surrounded by maternal blood in the lacunar space.
    • The trabeculae have now become the primary villi and the lacunar space, the intervillous space.
    • When the extraembryonic mesoderm invades this primary villus and forms the core, this structure becomes the secondary villi, with the mesoderm core covered by cytotrophoblast and then the syncytiotrophoblast.
    • Once the blood vessels fill the mesoderm, the tertiary villi are formed.
    • The maternal blood runs in the intervillous space, and the fetal blood in the villi.

questions.text: A woman who is Rh-negative is pregnant with a Rh-positive baby and is advised to take anti-D immunoglobulin for safe future pregnancies. Which of the following disappears from the placental membrane, thus thinning it out later in the pregnancy?

choices.text: The basement membrane of fetal capillaries

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Cytotrophoblasts

 

Explanation:

The placental membrane or barrier separates the maternal and fetal blood in the intrauterine period but thins out towards the end of pregnancy for many reasons, one of which is the disappearance of the cytotrophoblast.

 

Placenta has 2 parts (maternal and fetal), 2 surfaces (maternal and fetal), 2 types of cotyledons, and a peripheral margin.

  • Maternal part is formed by the decidua basalis or decidual plate of the endometrium.
  • Fetal part is from the chorion frondosum or chorionic plate.
  • Maternal surface is rough and irregular having maternal cotyledons.
  • Fetal surface is smooth and covered by amnion.
  • Peripheral margin of the placenta presents the fetal membrane formed from decidua capsularis and pareitalis, chorion laeve and amnion.
     

Placental Membrane:

  • This separates the fetal blood in the villi from the maternal blood in the intervillous space running side by side but opposite in direction.
  • The exchange of oxygen, nutrition, and waste products occurs through this membrane.
  • The following are the structures that form the placental membrane early in pregnancy:
    • Endothelium of maternal blood vessels and its basement membrane
    • Syncytiotrophoblast
    • Cytotrophoblast
    • Extraembryonic mesoderm (EEM)
    • Endothelium of fetal blood vessels and its basement membrane
  • Structures that form the placental membrane Later in pregnancy:
    • Endothelium of fetal capillaries and their basement membrane (Option B & C)
    • Syncytiotrophoblast (Option A)
  • The placental membrane thins later in pregnancy due to:
    • Disappearance of cytotrophoblast
    • Thinning of syncytiotrophoblast
    • Edematous stroma
    • Peripheral migration of fetal blood vessels
  • The total area of this membrane varies from 4 meter-squared to 14 meter-squared and is 0.025mm thick at first and later 0.002mm.

questions.text: What is the structure marked “C” formed of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Trophoblast + Somatopleuric EEM

 

Explanation:

The structure marked “C” is Chorion, which is formed by the parietal (or somatopleuric) extraembryonic mesoderm and the trophoblast.

Formation of extraembryonic mesoderm:

  • Extra embryonic mesoderm, also called the primary mesoderm, is a mass of cells formed from the cells of the yolk sac cells (Hueser’s membrane) and lies outside the embryonic disc.
  • This separates the endodermal layer covering the yolk sac and the trophoblast, as well as the wall of the amniotic cavity from the trophoblast.
  • It does not form any tissues of the embryo.


Formation of extraembryonic coelom:

  • The extraembryonic mesoderm develops small cavities that later coalesce into one large cavity called the extraembryonic coelom (chorionic cavity), which divides the extraembryonic mesoderm into two layers.
  • The layer between the amniotic cavity and the inside of the trophoblast is the parietal or somatopleuric extraembryonic mesoderm, and the layer outside the yolk sac is called the visceral or splanchnopleuric extraembryonic mesoderm.

 

Formation of connecting stalk:

  • The part of the extraembryonic mesoderm that keeps the amniotic sac, embryo, and yolk sac attached to the trophoblast, develops a structure called the connecting stalk.

 

Formation of chorion and amnion:

  • The parietal (or somatopleuric) extraembryonic mesoderm, cytotrophoblast and syncytiotrophoblast form a membrane called the chorion.
  • The amniogenic cells of the walls of the amniotic cavity and the parietal extraembryonic mesoderm form the amnion.
  • The amnion and chorion play a major role in childbirth.

questions.text: During the third week of gestation, the formation of the primitive streak signifies the start of gastrulation. Which statement about the primitive streak accurately describes this process?

choices.text: It forms from hypoblast cells and establishes the embryonic central axis.
It appears dorsally, becoming linear and marking the transition to a trilaminar disc.
It develops into the prechordal plate, defining the head-tail axis.
It originates from trophoblast cells, contributing to the amniotic cavity and yolk sac formation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It appears dorsally, becoming linear and marking the transition to a trilaminar disc.

 

Explanation:

  • The primitive streak is a key structure that forms on the dorsal aspect of the embryonic disc and becomes a linear structure as the disc elongates.
  • This marks the beginning of gastrulation and the transition from a bilaminar to a trilaminar disc, establishing the embryonic axis.

 

  • The primitive streak is an early, temporary structure that emerges in the blastula during the initial stages of embryonic development.
  • Around the 15th day of development, following the formation of the prechordal plate, epiblast cells along the central axis near the tail end of the embryo start to proliferate, creating an elevation that protrudes into the amniotic cavity known as the primitive streak. (Option A, B and D)
  • Its cranial end forms the primitive node.
  • A groove called a primitive groove appears in the primitive streak, which continues with a small depression, a primitive pit, in the primitive node.

questions.text: During embryonic development, different structures are derived from the lateral plate mesoderm. Which of the following structures are not derived from the lateral plate mesoderm?

choices.text: Smooth muscle layers of the gut
Visceral and Parietal layers of body cavities

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Smooth muscle of the iris

Explanation:

Smooth muscle of the iris (sphincter and dilator pupillae) is derived from mesenchymal cells originating from the ectoderm, not the lateral plate mesoderm.

 

Lateral Plate Mesoderm:

  • Located in the lateral part of the embryonic disc.
  • Splits into two layers due to the formation of the intraembryonic coelom. 

Somatopleuric (Parietal) Layer

Splanchnopleuric (Visceral) Layer

In contact with the ectoderm.

In contact with the endoderm.

Continuous with the somatopleuric extraembryonic mesoderm over the amnion.

Continuous with the splanchnopleuric extraembryonic mesoderm covering the yolk sac.
  • Forms the dermis of the skin in the body wall and limbs.
  • Contributes to bones and connective tissues of the limbs and sternum.
  • Sclerotome and muscle precursor cells that migrate into the parietal layer of lateral plate mesoderm form the costal cartilages, limb muscles, and most of the body wall muscles. (Option D)
  • Gives rise to shoulder and hip girdle bones. (Option A)
  • Forms a parietal layer around peritoneal, pleural, and pericardial cavities.
  • Forms connective tissue and smooth muscle layers of the gut, cardiac muscle, and the circulatory system. (Option B)
  • Form a visceral layer around peritoneal, pleural, and pericardial cavities.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with congenital abnormalities of both the kidneys and reproductive organs, including hypoplasia of the kidneys and abnormal development of the gonads. Which embryological structure is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Intermediate mesoderm

 

Explanation:

  • Intermediate mesoderm is crucial for the development of the nephrogenic cord (which forms the urinary system) and the genital ridge (which forms the genital system).
  • Abnormalities in this structure can result in both renal and gonadal defects.

 

Intermediate Mesoderm:

  • Lies between the paraxial mesoderm and the coelomic cavity in the lateral plate mesoderm before head folding.
  • After the folding of the embryonic disc and formation of the peritoneal cavity, it forms a bulge on the posterior abdominal wall, known as the urogenital ridge.

  • Urogenital Ridge:
    • Covered by coelomic epithelium.
    • Division:
      • Genital Ridge: Medial part; gives rise to the genital system.
      • Nephrogenic Cord: Lateral part; forms the urinary system and the adrenal cortex.
  • Nephrogenic Cord:
    • Extends from the cervical to the sacral region.
    • Structures Formed: 
  1. Excretory Renal Tubules: Para-, meso-, and metanephric tubules associated with kidney development.
  2. Nephric Duct: Initially forms in relation to the excretory tubules; later, it becomes the mesonephric duct.
  3. Adrenal Cortex: Forms from the mesoderm of the urogenital ridge, responsible for the development of the three layers of the adrenal cortex (zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, zona reticularis).
  4. Paramesonephric Duct: Forms lateral to the nephric duct.
  5. Gonad (Testis or Ovary): Develops from the coelomic epithelium lining the medial side of the nephrogenic cord.

Paraxial mesoderm (Option A) forms somites that give rise to the axial skeleton, skeletal muscles, and dermis of the skin. It does not primarily contribute to kidney or gonadal development.

 

Lateral plate mesoderm (Option C) contributes to the connective tissue of the body wall, limbs, and the visceral layers of the gut and circulatory system but does not directly form the kidneys or gonads.

 

Extraembryonic mesoderm (Option D) supports embryonic development by forming structures like the yolk sac, allantois, and chorionic villi, which are essential for placental and early embryonic support but do not directly form the kidneys or reproductive organs.

questions.text: An embryo is observed to have 12 pairs of somites on ultrasound. Based on this, what is the most likely developmental age of the embryo?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 23 days

 

Explanation:

  • Somites begin forming around day 20, and new somites form at a rate of approximately three pairs per day.
  • By 23 days, an embryo typically has about 12 pairs of somites, making this the most likely developmental age.

 

Somite Formation:

  • First pair of somites arises in the occipital region at approximately the 20th day of development.
  • Somites appear in a craniocaudal sequence at a rate of 3 pairs/day.
  • At the end of the fifth week: 42 to 44 pairs of somites are present.
  • Distribution: Occipital - 4, cervical - 8, thoracic - 12, lumbar - 5, sacral - 5, coccygeal - 8 to 10
  • The first occipital and last 5-7 coccygeal somites eventually disappear.
  • Remaining Somites: Contribute to the formation of the axial skeleton.
  • Clinical Application (Age Estimation): The age of an embryo can be accurately determined during this period by counting the number of somites.

 

Number of Somites Correlated to Approximate Age in Days

Approximate Age (days)

Number of Somites

20

1 - 4

21 (Option A)

4 - 7

22

7 - 10

23 (Option B)

10 - 13

24

13 - 17

25

17 - 20

26 (Option C)

20 - 23

27

23 - 26

28

26 - 29

30 (Option D)

34 - 35

questions.text: A newborn presents with scoliosis and underdeveloped axial muscles. Imaging reveals defects in the vertebral column. Which embryological structure is primarily responsible for the development of these affected tissues?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Paraxial Mesoderm

 

Explanation:

  • Paraxial mesoderm gives rise to somites, which further differentiate into the sclerotome (forming the vertebral column), myotome (forming skeletal muscles), and dermatome (forming dermis).
  • Defects in this structure can result in abnormalities in the axial skeleton (such as scoliosis) and skeletal muscles.

 

Intraembryonic Mesoderm/ Secondary Mesoderm:

  • Formed by the proliferation of cells from the primitive streak.
  • Separates the ectoderm and endoderm except in specific regions that remain bilaminar throughout life:
    • Prochordal plate (future oral cavity)
    • Cloacal membrane (future anal and urogenital openings)
    • Midline caudal to the prochordal plate

  • Subdivisions:

1. Paraxial Mesoderm

(Option A)

2. Lateral Plate Mesoderm

(Option B)

3. Intermediate Mesoderm

(Option C)

Located on either side of the notochord and becomes thick.

It forms a thinner layer located laterally.

A longitudinal strip found between the paraxial and lateral plate mesoderm.

It forms:

  • Somitomeres: Form mesoderm and muscles of the head and jaw.
  • Somites: Form midline axial skeleton, skeletal muscles and dermis of back.

It forms:

  • Somatopleuric (parietal) layer: Forms connective tissue of the body wall and limbs, such as appendicular skeleton bones , muscles and dermis of periphery.
  • Splanchnopleuric (visceral) layers: Forms connective tissue and smooth muscle layers of the gut, cardiac muscle and the circulatory system.

It forms:

  • Urinary and genital systems.

Extraembryonic Mesoderm/ Primary Mesoderm: (Option D)

  • Arises from the cells of the trophoblast.
  • Lies between the trophoblast and the endodermal cells lining the yolk sac.
  • Also separates the wall of the amniotic cavity from the trophoblast.
  • Classified as "extraembryonic" because it is located outside the embryonic disc.
  • Crucial in supporting embryonic development by forming tissues such as the yolk sac, allantois, and chorionic villi.

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct pairing of a structure and its corresponding embryological origin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Parotid gland – Surface ectoderm

 

Explanation:

The surface ectoderm gives rise to the Parotid gland.

 

Derivatives of Surface Ectoderm:

Structures

Derivatives

Epithelium & Glands
  • Skin epithelium
  • Sweat glands (Option A)
  • Sebaceous glands (Option B)
  • Myoepithelioctyes of skin

Eyes
  • Conjunctiva
  • Surface epithelium of cornea
  • Lens (Option D)

Salivary Glands
  • Parotid gland (Option C)
  • Submandibular gland
  • Sublingual gland

Opening Structures
  • Oral opening
  • Stomodeum
  • Proctodeum
  • Rathke pouch (Anterior pituitary)

questions.text: Which of the following components is responsible for the formation of sensory ganglia during embryonic development in the given figure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B

 

Explanation:

  • Neural crest cells are responsible for forming sensory ganglia, among other structures, during embryonic development.
  • In the above image, B denotes the neural crest cell.

Components of Ectoderm:

  • Neural Plate (Option D): Forms above the notochord and paraxial mesoderm; Develops into the central nervous system.
  • Neural Crest cells: Present dorsal to the neural tube at the edges of the neural plate.
    • Cells move throughout the embryo and contribute to various structures such as Dorsal root ganglia, autonomic ganglia, adrenal medulla, skin melanocytes, craniofacial skeleton, teeth odontoblasts etc.
  • Surface Ectoderm (Option C): Forms the epidermis, hair, glands, and other structures.
  • Placodal Ectoderm (Option A): Specialized ectodermal patches contributing to sensory structures (e.g., Otic, nasal, and lens placodes) and endocrine structures.

Derivatives of Ectoderm:

Surface Ectoderm

Neuroectoderm
  • Epidermis of the skin
  • Hair
  • Nails
  • Sweat & Sebaceous glands
  • Mammary glands
  • Enamel of the teeth
  • Lens of eye
  • Epithelium of sensory organs in the inner ear & nose
  • Nasolacrimal duct (NLD)
  • Anterior lobe of the pituitary gland
  • Central nervous system (Brain and spinal cord)
  • Peripheral nervous system
  • Retina
  • Sensory epithelia of nose & ear
  • Pineal gland
  • Posterior lobe of the pituitary gland

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the prechordal plate is incorrect?

choices.text: Forms the cephalocaudal axis of the embryo

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Derived from hypoblast cells

 

Explanation:

  • The prechordal plate is derived from epiblast cells, not hypoblast cells.
  • The epiblast is a layer of cells in the early embryo that gives rise to various important structures, including the prechordal plate.

Formation:

  • Lies between the tip of the notochord and the oropharyngeal membrane.
  • This is a small aggregation of mesodermal cells closely opposed to the endoderm.
  • It is derived from some of the first cells (epiblast cells) (Option A) that migrate from the primitive node at day 14.

Function and Role:

  • Establishes the central axis of the embryo, dividing it into right and left halves.
  • Helps distinguish the future head (cranial) and tail (caudal) ends of the embryo. (Option C)
  • Plays an essential role in inducing the development of the forebrain. 
  • The primordium of the oropharyngeal membrane, marking the future site of the oral cavity (mouth). 
  • There is no mesoderm in this region; direct contact occurs between the ectoderm and endoderm.
  • Notochord Formation: (Option D)  
  1. Formation of the primitive streak
  2. Migration of mesodermal cells through the primitive node
  3. Formation of the notochordal process
  4. Formation of the notochordal plate
  5. Detachment of the notochordal plate
  6. Rolling into the definitive notochord

questions.text: Which of the following correctly describes the sequence of events during gastrulation in the third week of gestation?

choices.text: Epiblast cells form the primitive streak, leading to the formation of the three germ layers.
The primitive streak forms at the cephalic end, initiating neural tube, gut, and cardiovascular development.
The prechordal plate forms after the notochord, and epiblast cells migrate to create the three germ layers.
The Endoderm forms from mesodermal cells, with ectoderm and mesoderm forming later.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Epiblast cells form the primitive streak, leading to the formation of the three germ layers.

 

Explanation:

  • During gastrulation, epiblast cells migrate to form the primitive streak.
  • This migration leads to the differentiation of epiblast cells into the three germ layers: endoderm, mesoderm, and ectoderm. 

Start of Process
  • Formation of the primitive streak on the surface of the epiblast.

Primitive Streak
  • Initially indistinct, it becomes a narrow groove with bulging regions by days 15-16.

Primitive Node
  • Located at the cephalic end of the streak, a slightly raised area surrounding a small pit.

Cell Migration
  • Epiblast cells migrate toward the primitive streak and undergo invagination.

Invagination
  • Cells transform into flask-shaped forms, detach from the epiblast, and move beneath it.

Regulation
  • Fibroblast growth factor 8 (FGF8) regulates cell movement and mesoderm formation.
  • FGF8 decreases E-cadherin levels, which helps in migration

Cell Spread
  • Invaginated cells replace the hypoblast and spread laterally and cranially.

Contact with Extraembryonic Mesoderm
  • Cells establish contact with the extraembryonic mesoderm covering the yolk sac and amnion.

Prechordal Plate
  • Forms between the notochord tip and the oropharyngeal membrane.
  • Important for forebrain induction.

Oropharyngeal Membrane
  • Composed of tightly joined ectoderm and endoderm cells.
  • Will become the future oral cavity opening.

Formation of Germ Layers
  • Endoderm: Displaces the hypoblast.
  • Mesoderm: Forms between the epiblast and endoderm.
  • Ectoderm: Develops from the Remains of the epiblast.

Outcome
  • The epiblast gives rise to all embryonic tissues and organs through the process of gastrulation.
